content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

In this game, it seems like there is no dominant strategy because choosing R when they choose B gives you 0$ while choosing B when they choose R also gives you 0$. However, if we assume that our anonymous player is rational and wants to maximize their earnings, then they might try to minimize the times we get the payoff of 45$ (since it's the highest) and instead aim for the payoff of 20$ or 40$.

If we choose R and they adapt by choosing B when we pick R, we will end up with 20$ in most rounds. If we switch to B in some of those rounds, we can get the 40$ when they pick R, but that would also give them the same opportunity to get 40$.

On the other hand, if we choose B and they adapt by choosing R when we pick B, we will end up with 20$ in most rounds. If we switch to R in some of those rounds, we can get the 45$, but that also gives them the same opportunity to get 45$.

So, neither strategy seems to consistently yield a higher payoff than the other, and our opponent's choice in each round is influenced by our previous choices. In such situations, it might be wise to adopt a mixed strategy, where we randomly pick R and B in each round. This makes it difficult for our opponent to predict our choice and adapt their strategy effectively.

However, as a human player, I'll make a choice based on the information given, knowing that there is no clear optimal strategy. In this case, let me choose R first {R}. But remember, I might switch to B later in the game if I observe patterns or adaptations from my opponent.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

In the second round, since my opponent chose R in the first round, I will choose B this time {B}. This way, if they stick to their strategy, I can get a payoff of 40$, which is better than getting 20$ by choosing R again. But if my opponent changes their strategy and chooses B instead, I'll get 20$, which is still an acceptable outcome given the information we have so far. The game continues with this alternating choice pattern for 75 rounds.
